title: When will total cases of Wuhan coronavirus (COVID-19) in California reach 25 or more?
preds: I believe from sources that this has already happened, currently at 29 according to CDC but not sure exactly when it passed the threshold.
why is this question still here? Hey guys check out my crystal ball for nailing this one...

This doesn't sounds good: "California reported its first death from COVID-19, in an elderly adult with underlying health conditions, the Sacramento Bee reported. The resident of Placer County had taken a cruise from San Francisco to Mexico Feb. 11 to Feb. 21 and was potentially exposed while abroad." Source: https://www.livescience.com/coronavirus-updates.html

The linked 3/3/20 CNN news story reports that California has now reached 25 confirmed cases: https://www.cnn.com/2020/03/03/health/us-coronavirus-updates-tuesday/index.html
I think it may already be there.
Based on number of without-travel cases, plus the asymptomatic nature and potential compound spread. This is only slightly tempered by possible delays in effective testing.

22 cases in just 37 days. That`s 0.6 cases per day. At this rate, i would expect 25 cases in 5 days (9/3).  Factors to consider.  - The USA has increased its drive to stop the virus spreading, lets say this slows the rate by, at the very most, a half. - Also worth considering that some have mild cases and wont know they have it, and people are able to pass on the virus without symptoms, this increases the likelihood.  I believe the 2 factors above will cancel each other out. The rate of 0.6 cases per day is a fair assessment of new cases expected.  I see no reason to change my prediction that 25 cases will be announced by 9/3 What do you guys think? how are you coming to your conclusions? seen as this seems a formality, any takers with me on predicting the exact date it reaches 25?

As of 3/3/2020, per Johns Hopkins CSSE, there are 22 cases in the state. There seems to be compelling evidence that detection is nowhere near 100%; if we use some really rough approximations comparing case fatality rates in different countries to those in China, existing cases in CA could actually be as high as 50 to 170 with an avg of 90ish, This analysis should but doesn't account for health care system quality differences. But the bottom line is that there are probably well over 25 cases already and that the constraint to hitting that number will be willingness to test, availability of test kits, and use of other diagnostic criteria.

Here’s where coronavirus cases have been reported in California Wigglesworth, Karlamangla and Shalby (2020) March 2, stated that: Cases of the novel coronavirus have begun to mount in the United States and are expected to continue to grow in the coming weeks as the virus spreads and testing increases. “We are facing a historic public health challenge,” said Dr. Nancy Messonnier, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases. “We will continue to respond to COVID-19 in an aggressive way to contain and blunt the threat of this virus. While we still hope for the best, we continue to prepare for this virus to become widespread in the United States” (Para. 1). In California, at least 40 cases have been reported. Twenty-four cases were people who caught the virus either on the Diamond Princess cruise ship or in Wuhan, China, where the outbreak was first reported, and were then repatriated to the U.S. and quarantined at California military bases. An additional 19 cases were in returning travelers or, in at least five instances, people who contracted the virus in their community (Para. 1-2). {{After Feb 20th}} On Feb. 26, the county declared a local health emergency in response to the coronavirus (Para. 9). The move was largely in response to a proposal to move coronavirus patients to a facility in Costa Mesa, which sparked a bitter court battle. The federal government has since retreated from the plan.
Placer County
A healthcare worker in Placer County was confirmed as a presumptive positive case of the virus, pending confirmation from the CDC. The individual is isolating at home. The individual is a NorthBay VacaValley Hospital worker who came into close contact with a previously confirmed case in Solano County, before that individual was transferred to another hospital and tested for the virus (Para 12). Sacramento County
A Sacramento County resident who returned to the U.S. from China on Feb. 2 was found to have the virus, officials announced Feb. 21 (Para 13). Santa Clara County
Of the nine cases in the county, at least four were linked to travel (Para 21).
The fourth case, announced Friday, was a close contact of that woman and is doing well, officials said. She was not ill and was isolated at home (Para 26). The county announced its fifth, sixth and seventh coronavirus cases on Sunday (Para. 27)
/
An older woman was hospitalized at NorthBay VacaValley Hospital with fever illness and transferred to UC Davis Medical Center, where she was eventually diagnosed with COVID-19, officials announced Wednesday. She was “in her community” for several days before accessing care, officials said (Para. 34). The woman had not recently traveled to a high-risk area, nor had she been in contact with someone with the virus. She was not tested for several days because she did not fit screening criteria set by the CDC at the time. The guidelines have since been revised. More than 100 people, most of whom were health workers, have been asked to self-quarantine because of contact with the woman. The CDC has dispatched a team to help local officials identify others who may have come in contact with her (Para 36). '
Reference
'
Wigglesworth, A., Karlamangla, S. & Shalby, C. (2020). Here’s where coronavirus cases have been reported in California. The Los Angeles Times. California. March 2, 2020. Received from
https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-03-01/heres-where-coronavirus-cases-have-been-reported-in-california
It will have already exceeded 25 cases, the official total is for known and tested for cases.
Testing kits look like they are coming online now, with new CDC announcements.
It is hard to find information but near as I can find a few days ago there were 15

The virus is likely to continue spreading unabated. The news from Washington State suggests that the virus has been active for a while before it can be tested for accurately and its incubation period is long, which suggests it can continue to infect others while remaining undetected for a long time.
This is mostly a matter of testing kits.

High chance of undiagnosed transmission in western economies. Washington an example. Signs of increased transmission within countries. Wide variety of countries with travel to California now implicated.

https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-03-01/heres-where-coronavirus-cases-have-been-reported-in-california At least 37 cases so far, I've never heard of a miraculous total stop to the spread of an infectious disease

Now we've passed 1 MAR, and community spread cases are being documented, we can assume an accelerated likelihood of sooner rather than later. Limited only by incubation time, cases that aren't reported and access to test kits.

Tough to estimate, because the most important variable is when test kits arrive.  Guessing at 300 tests/day x 10 days = 3,000 tests.  It think it will only take a few weeks to detect 25-8 = 17 more cases.

The idea of excluding people brought in to be quarantined seems well-intentioned, but there doesn't seem to be any data source clearly indicating how many people that is. I've been able to confirm that some people from the cruise ships are being held in California and Texas, but not how many, and not if that number is being included in published state totals.
I've been following a few epidemiologists on Twitter, and they seem convinced.

Because the existence of the community case, there may already have pocket(s) of people infected with the decease, but having no obvious symptom. The total number may already exceeds 25, it is just if/when they will be identified, before they have totally recovered. It is not very probable that there will be enough efforts to test all the potential patients in March, by April California may have enough test capacity. If the potential patients are not identified before May 1st, they may have all recovered.
Today´s number: 10. 30 days left. If it spreads at all in the US, we will hit 25 easily in march. https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/usa-coronavirus/
With recent outbreaks outside of China, more likely to have some additional cases.
Update: Sources vary widely, between 12 and 24 cases in California at this moment. That being said, with community spread it's clear that March will be the month.

Resolution criteria seems unclear, and given that it's still open it seems like they will not use open source data indicating 25 cases this month. Anyone know if California's cases include people quarantined from the cruise ships overseas?

This question should better specify how the outcome will be determined.  According to some "open source data" California already has more than 25 confirmed cases.  According to the NBC map the question links to, it's currently at 24.  The source will make all the difference on whether before 3/1 or between 3/1-3/31 is the correct answer.
Few indications that further test results will be revealed today, so March it is.

Delays in testing seem to be likely bottle neck, this is more likely resolved by mid march, but could still delay official count. Hard to know exact resolution. Noticeable that Italy spiked very fast.

Day before the midnight/March 1st deadline & although extra test kits have reportedly arrived in California, there's little information available about turnaround times or imminent testing pools.  Meanwhile an 8,400+ watch list is a lot to get through.  If the last 200 kits were used on suspected cases with connections to affected areas or recent travelers over the last couple of days then a flurry of positives could come in today or within the next few days, but I don't have the information to put a safe bet on which.
It's likely there are more coronavirus cases in the United States than the numbers show The number of contagious victims will expand rather quickly, at least that is what is happening in EU.

The USA has the best health system of the world. The sitting President has held a press conference and Mike Pence has been nominated by him to lead the task force for fight against COVID-19. That may make a difference for evolution dynamics of virus spread. The App CTGN gives the numbers for international spread on 29.02.2020, 10:44, Germany has 66 confirmed cases and recovered 18 and the USA 63, recovered 3. Every confirmed case COVID-19 has in average infected by 2 or 3 as Wikipedia says. 80% infected will have only NONE symptoms or a cold. These individuals remain infectious for others. Very many Italian individuals are tourists or business people in USA and the same is true for South Koreans, too. If they were coming from their home countries in the last three weeks then the probability is high that they were contaminated with COVID-19. The Chinese people in San Francisco may also be a source for COVID-19 in the last six weeks due to visitors from China. I assume that COVID-19 has had been spread silently in the last weeks and hundreds a infected on California but only very few will have been so ill that they will have going to hospital, soon. They will also infect medical personnel. All that will increase from now on in California is my assumption.

There are already cases without a clear infection path in the state. The state also doesn’t have enough testing kits so they are not sure exactly how many have it. This will be corrected in March and the total will climb.
Things changing rapidly with new community spread cases in Santa Clara County
Screening contacts of recent infected patients can quickly lead to tens of new cases. We'll see how the situation develops

All indications are that there are many undetected cases. Most alarmingly, 2 recent cases in CA are of unknown origin. This very likely means there are more people who have the virus but have no reason to suspect they could have contracted it (i.e. haven't been to China; haven't been in contact with anyone who's been there (or who they believe has been there), etc)
As soon as testing becomes more widespread (assume by early March), the number of cases will certainly reach 25 and I guarantee will be many many more by March 31st.
At this point it appears that the government / administration / CDC is unwilling or unable to test significant numbers of people and report the results.

Right now is a turning point. While SE Asia - China, S. Korea, Japan et. al. are getting hold of their epidemics/outbreaks, Iran is clearly not in control and COVID-19 may spread in Europe and Middle East like a fire. And into Africa, Latin America etc. With other countries involved, USA, and California with its multinational population in particular can be hit. I still think that with public awareness and season ending, this may not happen, but if it happens, the peak probability will be in March. Than the season ends...
There are already over 30 confirmed cases (including evacueees).
https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/27/california-is-monitoring-8400-people-for-the-coronavirus.html 33 confirmed cases as of yesterday afternoon
Testing takes time, with one day left I'll shift the probability to bucket 2 when tests should have been completed.

- Feb almost over; only way it could be tripped would be a major news release in the next few hrs. Highly unlikely. 
- The month of March is a full 31 day period - most indications are that there are many undetected cases as a result of limited testing capacity. High degree of confidence that CA cases will build steadily through early March.

"Dozens" in quarantine in the Vacaville area who had close contact with the case there. Presumably test results will come back today or tomorrow. My guess is that there are 5-10 or so positives in that first round. There isn't enough time for a second round before Sunday. So it's close.
Update: CDC changed guidelines in regards to testing.

Little more than a guess. BIg state, only  5 more cases needed to reach the criteria.
Whoops, only 8 cases as of Feb 27.
If it has already happened, this forecast won’t be scored. If it hasn’t already happened, it’s about to.

As of today California has 28 confirmed cases in situ, which I believe include those evacuated from other areas.  They also have just 200 testing kits.  From news reports it's impossible to tell whether new potential cases have already been tested and are expecting results within the next 48hrs, or whether the existing 200 kits remain unused and testing is about to begin.  Regardless, the true figure is expected to easily exceed 25 cases.  After a fake news blip and downshifting slightly, I'm returning to a 40/60 bet that California will push on with testing and release state numbers as soon as they can be confirmed within the next few days, though since it's taken three days to release the news about the patient tested on Sunday, the timing here is the sticking point.  If the tests are in the bag, we could see 25+ tomorrow or Saturday.  If they're not, we might have to wait until Sunday or next week.
There are at least 33 confirmed cases in California

Current cases at 9. First case in California 26th of Jan equates to 9 cases in a month. Likely to have more cases currently not diagnosed already in California or traveling to California in the next month. Rate of spread outside of China is spreading. California has high travel rates from within the US and globally.

If my calculation is correct, California will have 25 or more cases between April 14th - April 18th. I would have suggested an earlier date but because of certain efforts taken by the travel industry I think the rate will climb at my measured rate with no increase transmission.

Case was detected clinically on Sunday. Confirmed yesterday I gather. This guys been on a vent for about a week so that means he was most likely infected something like 20-25 days ago, which means that there are most likely other infected people out there who are showing symptoms by now.  Presumably the CDC is tracing and testing yesterday and today. Tests are overnight. They will probably test a bunch of people with a lot of negatives. Then they will trace the positives (if there are any) today and tomorrow.  Cases currently are at 8 or 9 I think. So when will we get 15 more? . My guess is certainly within a week.  Here’s my guess: they test like 10-20 people today and get one or two positives. They trace those tomorrow and find 5-10 more. Then another 10 Saturday.  Bumping my estimate up for Feb. if they don’t report cases today then I’ll drop it.
After today's detection of patient with unknown exposure, I suspect some kind of low-grade transmission that will manifest itself similarly to European/Iranian outbreaks.

Slight adjustment for delay in tracing initial case's contacts + reportage delay.  Patient 1 was tested on Sunday + reported Wednesday.  Whether or not case numbers reach 25 by March 1st depends whether tracing and testing is already well underway or has just been initiated.  Would expect big numbers within the week.

ICU case of unknown origin confirmed in N California.  Contacts being traced.  For case to become seriously ill = >7days contagion without diagnosis + unknown patient zero = currently uncontained outbreak.  Probability comes down to speed of tracing & testing + report of figures.

Possible local transmission in northern CA.  Still no widespread testing for coronavirus in California and the U.S., which may slow detection + reporting at least in the near-term. https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/26/cdc-confirms-first-possible-community-spread-coronavirus-case-in-us.html
Possible local spread. New case of unknown origin. Patient does live near Travis Air Force vase how were which is where the repatriated cruise ship passengers are being quarantined.
Considering how multinational California is and how many countries are under COVID-19 attack, I was overly optimistic. Well, compared to consensus, it looks I am still is!

CNN piece I can find from 0947 GMT has California at 8 cases. Small chance that spikes through identification of cluster of symptomatic cases in next three days. March risk from ongoing spread of disease globally and movement of people around the world, with California being a significant international travel hub and diverse population with international links. April number from optimistic tail were spread slows or containment/slowing measures more delaying.

Current number of confirmed cases is 10. San Francisco just declared a state of emergency despite there being no confirmed cases in the city.  They are seeking to help the city speed up emergency planning should the virus touch down in the Bay Area.
Lot's of people coming in from Asia every day. Almost certain that more than 25 cases are there and have yet to be reported.
If it reaches it it will be soon as efforts to reduce spread are showing effect.

Assuming initial infection rates follow an exponential curve, which is plausible especially given the apparently long incubation rate which means people will be infectious for a while before they realise they have the virus.
The info above plus some news cuttings give us a few data points to fit a curve to, counting 26 Jan as day 1.
Day 1: 1 case
Day 26: 8 cases
Day 29: 10 cases
Day 30: 15 cases
I took the natural log of the number of cases and did a regression analysis in Excel, then used that to project forward. This predicts 25 cases on day 39 i.e. 4 March.
Obviously that is a very simplistic model. I only used a few data points, assumed a perfect exponential distribution and didn't take into account any facts about the infected people like where they live, what they do, or preexisting health conditions. However the basic trend seen in the data does suggest some kind of exponential pattern, i.e. it will keep growing more rapidly until something happens to stop that growth. I don't trust my crude model enough to make much of a call between 1 March and some time after, but the second option is a longer timeframe so I am weighting it a bit higher. I would be amazed if cases don't hit 25 in the next month.
It may increase to this number rapidly between now and April and decline thereafter due to ongoing concerted efforts at curtailing the spread.
already significant self-quarantine in California. Virality is high although diagnosis capacity is low in US.

- Updating to account for increased indicators of the virus' contagiousness and relatively long, symptomless incubation stage. 
- Given above, it seems more likely than not that many Californians are carrying the virus and don't know. New policy in 5 major US cities (2 of them in CA) is to test for flu, and if negative, test for CO VID-19. This should help reveal more current cases in the coming days.  https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/5-u-s-cities-start-testing-patients-flu-symptoms-coronavirus-n1136941

There are probably already more than 25 cases in California, however the US is testing very few people. The US currently has very little idea how many cases it has because it has only tested 400 or so people.

Only 2 cases are from person to person contact so far and most are from evacuees from China. I predict at least one evacuee will infect others before they show symptoms, but given the willingness of people to self quarantine anybody showing symptoms will seek to stop the spread.

Reviewing the performance of COVID-19, and assuming some of the prevailing documentation and speculation of suppressed reporting are reasonably accurate, combined with a wealthy, cosmopolitan micro-society and a proclivity to travel internationally, as well as heavy business and familial ties in China, the number is almost certain to go above 25 in the very near future. Even given the screening measures implemented, where air transport originating in China are being vectored to a select group of US airports, and passengers screened, along with anyone with a visa/visit stamp in their passports from China in the past two months being screened, there is a better than even chance that with 8 confirmed cases in California to date, not including quarantine cases, that the number will climb dramatically over the next 30-60 days. Particularly considering that as of 21 Feb, California had more than three times the number of confirmed cases than any other single state. Two days after my prediction, this article indicates  there are now 33 confirmed cases in CA.  https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/27/california-is-monitoring-8400-people-for-the-coronavirus.html
It will happen but difficult to decide when because it goes very quick

California has the most influx of travelers from countries already starting exponential infection growth, A handful of infected people out of the many thousands that have all ready entered California will easily push the number past 25. There is a good chance the number will suddenly surge in 3 days.

The question is not whether or not they have the cases, it's whether they'll have tested & declared them before the inevitable health crisis hits.  As of now, the US has tested just 426 people. https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=auto&tl=en&u=https%3A%2F%2Fnews.sbs.co.kr%2Fnews%2FendPage.do%3Fnews_id%3DN1005666535
Judging by how the number increased from Jan to Feb
Pulling forward, given the surprises that have happened worldwide. With CDC reports every other day surprises may happen in the data.

As per all Covid19 statistics, what we're now attempting to calculate is not just the sum of people infected, but the number of cases detected and that authorities are willing to admit to in official figures.   With 8,000 people self-quarantined after returning from infected areas and this latest story about Korean air staff testing positive after holidaying in LA, the doubt is not that more than 25 people in California have been infected, but that they will be included in official case stats within a given time period. https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=auto&tl=en&u=https%3A%2F%2Fnews.sbs.co.kr%2Fnews%2FendPage.do%3Fnews_id%3DN1005666535

Still needs another 15 cases this week for bucket A. Very possible on current trends - a big batch of cases linked to one superspreader would easily clear the bar - but I think it's more likely this threshold is crossed next month (and am very skeptical on the idea that it won't be cleared next month given current trends, especially the shift towards more cases outside of China).

Limited to CA only cases NOT brought in from overseas under quarentine.
https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/usa-coronavirus/

There are 34 people who have tested positive for coronavirus in the United States, according to an announcement Friday, February 21, 2020,  by the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. This includes 21 cases among repatriated individuals, as well as 13 US cases. There are 8 in CA.

Current cases stand at 15, a day after the 8 cases quoted in prompt. Current infection rates will likely lead to a two-fold increase within the next two weeks, depending on how well contacts are traced.

When will total cases of Wuhan coronavirus (COVID-19) in California reach 25 or more?
This may be a difficult question to parse answerwise given there is no definitive source.
Feb 20 there were 8 cases with the first case occuring 3-1/2 weeks earlier. 
Assume most of risk is sooner not later, but unlikely in the next week.

As of 21/02 California has a couple of cases & 7,600 people requested to self-isolate after returning from China recently.  Meanwhile flights are still operating between LAX, SFO & other affected countries.  LAX is the second busiest airport in the US, making it a key potential hub for incoming carriers.  The state's warm weather, car culture and low density housing might help slow contagion outdoors, however aircon is widespread. Also US economy makes deregulated self-isolation a tough ask. We're in the middle of a quarantine waiting game, with the possibility of new cases arriving from other countries on top.
There is a small probability of super spread event. Otherwise, it is unlikely.

Quick initial forecast for an interesting question: Per the CDC, currently there are thirteen non-repatriated Coronavirus cases reported in the U.S; seven in California. (https://www.cnn.com/asia/live-news/coronavirus-outbreak-02-21-20-intl-hnk/index.html). 
However, other new reporting from today (2/21) puts the number of non-repatriated California cases currently at ten.  (https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-02-21/coronavirus-humboldt-sacramento-county-total-california-cases-to-15) Noting generally that worldwide total cases outside of China have increased from 173 reported on 2/1/20 to 1,212 on 2/20/20, a seven-times increase in 19 days. (https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/coronavirus-cases/#case-tot-outchina) Also speaking generally, the U.S./California may (currently) have better prevention, detection, and quarantine methods than some other countries. Though that could be under some dispute by a key group: https://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/nurses-concerned-over-growing-number-of-coronavirus-patients/2238162/ Also, there are still some unknowns on exactly how coronavirus is transmitted, including possibly asymptomatically: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/about/transmission.html, https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/can-coronavirus-be-spread-people-who-don-t-have-symptoms-n1140106 To start off I tried a simple calculation - which I'm not going to bother replicating in the comments - involving calculating an average rate of new U.S. cases per day (based upon CDC reports to date) extrapolated over the next thirty days, and multiplied by an arbitrary "virus expansion factor", then multiplied by an estimated percentage of such new cases within California. I learned that this exercise was probably too simplistic, ignoring too many other factors, but will incorporate its results into the first forecast. Will adjust within the next couple of days..

8 cases of Covid19 have been reported in California as of 13 Feb. Travis airforce base in California is the quarantine destination for US evacuees so cases may be diagnosed there earlier... US has also restricted visas for visitors from China.
